May peace and grace from God through Jesus Christ be upon you.It is well to begin with a plan when undertaking any task, so that in the execution of it nothing may be wanting.It is my advice then, that you proceed in the following manner:When debates and disputations arise among Christians concerning matters of faith, they should be decided and elucidated by the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments.
Then state the proposition plainly.When it has been publicly read, proclaim, "If any one differs, let him come forward."You must exact a profession of the Old Testament, wherever it may be latent.When they attempt to introduce and urge arguments to the contrary, you must take care not to be moved from the proposition, but only answer what is necessary; and always keep your eye on the proposition.You must not depart from the Scriptures, nor yield to any arguments, till it be manifest that they have no regard to the proposition, nor overthrow it; and then you must proceed no farther.Let there be a silence until the objections are answered.None must interpose but to the purpose, only taking care that their answers be satisfactory.

We can clearly see from 1 Corinthians 14:28 and 1 Thessalonians 5:19 that one should remain silent in the church if they don't have an interpreter and that one should not extinguish the Spirit. What could be clearer than this? We must now show from the Holy Scriptures how this should be interpreted.
First of all, one must not just cite one passage of Scripture, but rather cite other passages that oppose it. Otherwise, the devil will prevail, as is seen in Matthew 4 and 22. Here, the Sadducees produced Scriptures, but Jesus opposed it with clearer and more relevant passages.
Secondly, we should interpret obscure passages with clearer ones, as Peter taught in 2 Peter 1. The passage should also be understood in the context of faith and love. This is seen in Christ's words in Matthew 19, Paul's words in Romans 4 and 1 Corinthians 12 and James' words in James 2.
From this, it follows that this interpretation is based on the Scriptures. Moreover, when the lesser contradicts the greater, the obscure contradicts the clear, and the passages should be interpreted according to faith and love.
Therefore, we must be sure that people agree with this interpretation and not leave until they have subscribed to it. We also must be careful not to pile up similar passages under the guise of interpretation. The passages that we use to interpret must be clearer than the one in question, or be in opposition to it, so that one can see that there is a different meaning than what is expressed by the words. Then, one must carefully consider the context, preceding and following passages, faith and love.
So, now that we have discussed this, we will find that the work here is less. If they do not want to come to this conclusion, show them that it is not right to avoid coming to a conclusion using a single passage, but rather to act in a timely, safe and sure manner.

It is well to begin with well-arranged plans, that in the action itself there may be nothing to darken and confound that which ought to have been settled and determined. Therefore, after prayer and preface, immediately set forth this proposition: That all disputes and controversies among Christians concerning matters of faith, should be decided and explained by the Holy Scriptures of the Old and New Testament. And when this proposition shall have been publicly read, cry out, “If any man think differently, let him come forth.” Then search out, if any one should be found to deny the authority of the Old Testament. When they come forward, and begin to dispute, take care to prove, that they do not depart from the proposition, nor draw any thing from it which is not consistent with it; and still keep an eye upon the proposition. And let nothing be passed by, nor yield, till it be manifest that they have no regard to the proposition, and that it will not serve their purpose. And let all be done in silence, to the end that the matter may be determined with speed.

Let us talk now, let us see if we should interpret the Scripture literally or if we should explain it. Saying that we should interpret it literally, here are some examples: "My Father is greater than I" [John 14:28], "This is my body" [Mark 14:22], "Unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man" [John 6:53], "Pluck out your eye" [Matthew 5:29], "He who has been bathed needs only to wash his feet" [John 13:10]. We must therefore explain it. But how? This is what is being disputed. So they should show the way. If they show the wrong way, oppose them! If they show the right way, write it down! And in order that you may make all things clear as was briefly mentioned in the first article, that you always act with caution lastly. What I have to say about this I share with you.
It is proven that Scripture is to be explained by examples:
1. Christ who explained the law in Matthew 5 [17ff], the passage of Isaiah from chapter 61 [1f] in Luke 4 [17ff], and Scriptures to the disciples in Luke 24 [27].
2. Peter, who explained some passages in the Acts and letters, and testified that some understood Paul in a distorted sense: 2 Peter 3 [16].
3. The Church which explains Psalm 2 [1f]: Acts 4 [24ff].
4. Philip who explained Isaiah to the eunuch: Acts 8 [35].
5. Paul who explained many things in the Acts, in Romans about Abraham and others, in 1 Corinthians 5 [7] about the Passover, and much in Galatians chapters 3 and 4.
6. Most clearly in 1 Corinthians 14 [28]: "If there is no interpreter, let him keep silent in the church" etc., and: "Do not quench the Spirit" etc.: 1 Thessalonians 5 [19]. What could be clearer than these words?
Now we will teach from the very Scriptures how it is to be explained:
1. It is not enough to produce one passage unless other passages are opposed. Otherwise the devil would have won: Matthew 4 [1ff]. The Sadducees: Matthew 22 [23ff]. He brought Scriptures, but opposed both contrary and clearer passages.
2. Therefore, obscure passages should be explained with clearer ones, as Peter teaches in 2 Peter 1 [19ff].
3. The passage itself should be explained according to the circumstances, faith, and love. I prove it: Thus Christ acted with the bill of divorcement, Matthew 19 [3ff], Paul with the words "imputed", Romans 4 [3ff], 1 Corinthians 12.13 [?], James 2 [21ff].
From all this it follows that this is supported by Scriptures and drawn out from Scriptures. Likewise, where there is less, by the greater, the obscure by the clearer, according to faith and love, all is directed.
Here pay special attention that they stop disagreeing and agree, and do not leave until they subscribe. For this it will be useful that later in the discussion neither boast of their own spirit nor use only the letter, and if they have produced Scripture passages, they must prove the sense from the Scriptures and ask for testimonies from the Scriptures.
Then you will be freely able to say everywhere: "Now prove the understanding with Scripture or I will turn your understanding with Scripture." This requires a man who has been trained in the Scriptures, but the surest victory is to be hoped for.
Also be careful not to pile up passages which are completely similar in appearance. The passages which we wish to explain must either be clearer than the one about which the dispute is, or contrary, so that everyone can see from the opposition that there is another sense than that which the words carry. Here above all the circumstances, the preceding, the following, faith, and love should be examined.
This is all.
Then take up the articles first, and you will find that the work in this will be less.
